title: Carsten Schwemmer
text:
Chair
Faculty of Social Sciences



carsten.schwemmer@lmu.de



Website 1










Mission Statement
I am a professor of Computational Social Sciences at the Department of Sociology. For computational research, two major challenges related to open science are a) the inability to share data, which is often proprietary and b) complexity of computing environments, which makes it difficult to replicate results across systems. I am interested in research opportunities that can help to address both of these challenges.

title: Balthasar Schachtner
text:
Researcher
Faculty of Medicine



balthasar.schachtner@med.uni-muenchen.de



Website 1










Mission Statement
I am a postdoctoral researcher at the Clinical Data Science group at the Department of Radiology, investigating the feasibility of applying machine-learning-based algorithms on medical images for common tasks in radiology. In a rapidly evolving field, lack of reproducibility can lead to an erosion of trust in publications with seemingly promising results. Therefore I'm convinced that disseminating and living the principles and ideas of Open Science will allow us to produce trustworthy scientific results, while accelerating scientific progress by enabling a larger and more diverse audience to participate in the process.

title: Adam Sorbie

adam.sorbie@med.uni-muenchen.de



Website 1










Mission Statement
I am a postdoc working in the Institute for Stroke and Dementia Research at the LMU University Hospital. My research focuses on the involvement of the microbiota in modulating stroke severity and outcome. Working in this relatively new field, I have noticed many datasets or code are not publicly available and those that are, often exclude critical metadata or other information necessary to reproduce findings. I believe in my field and others this hampers translational research and thus aim to actively encourage open science practices. In this context I am particularly passionate about data/code sharing and the use and development of software which facilitates open science.

Personally, I am commited to make it easy for others to replicate what I do, as it is the only way to review the procedures, to spot inconsistencies, and to provide new ideas to make science advance.

Mission Statement

Sharing methodology, pre-specifying analyses and independent replication are the best tools to solve the reproducibility crisis. I’m looking forward to working with the Open Science center in order to promote Open Science.

Mission Statement
I am Caspar and I'm currently enrolled in the B.Sc Psychology program, where my academic focus and research interest lies in the realm of social- and personality psychology, as well as Open Science and Science Communication.

Occasionally, when time permits, I participate in the ReproducibiliTea Journal Club?a forum dedicated to discussions on crucial aspects of research methodology.

Mission Statement
I am professor for Behavioural Ecology at the Faculty of Biology

I specialize on biodiversity in the broad sense, with a focus on understanding patterns of variation (among genotypes, individuals) within single populations, particularly in the context of behaviour. Much of our work is starting to involve large-scale collaborations to perform study replications to understand whether study-specific results are generally applicable, for example through the SPI-Birds Network. Open and reproducible science are important for making such enterprises successful. My work also involves developing and teaching complex statistics, particularly mixed-model analyses. I am have many years of editorial experience for high-quality journals, and because of such experiences am convinced we need to move our community to conduct transparent, reproducible, and open science.

Mission Statement

To me, openness and transparency are core values of scientific practice. I try to implement them in my own work by following Open Science practices, and I try to communicate them to students and colleagues in lectures and workshops. As a researcher in psychological methods, I also contribute to methodological reform by finding adequate approaches for planning studies and analyzing data. title: Peter Edelsbrunner
text:
Chair
Faculty of Psychology & Education



peter.edelsbrunner@lmu.de



Website 1










Mission Statement
As an educational psychologist with a background in quantitative methods, I got in contact with the emerging open science movement around 2010, when the triplet of the Bem-controversy, Stapel-case, and Ioannidis-paper got it all started. I enjoy doing open science, thinking about meta-science, and being part of a slow yet daring process towards improvement.

In the spirit of the great thinker and educator John Dewey, I live and teach open science as a process of continuous growth rather than a fixed skill set, defending the position that socially constructed justification is more important than rigid rules and norms. Practices I use most are open data and materials, and I prefer unblinded and transparent reviewing.

I edited journal issues on registered reports in understudied populations and daring methodologies in Psychology, and have been part of many analysts- endeavors.

For me, open science practices are demanding and require continuous effort and improvement, so I highly appreciate anyone's engagement.

Mission Statement
Malika Ihle is the LMU Open Science Center Coordinator, supporting the scientific board in developing a comprehensive approach to open research that extends across all disciplines, using both bottom-up and top-down strategies. Her role is to provide peer-to-peer training and develop an open research curriculum, coordinate grassroots initiatives and organise various events such as seminars and conferences, support meta-research collaborations, liaise with local, national (e.g. the German Reproducibility Network (GRN)), and international stakeholders to inform the design of incentives and policies, and co-develop a strategic plan to make the LMU Open Science Center a sustainable entity.

title: Annie Chan
text:
Researcher
Faculty of Study of Culture



a.chan@lmu.de



Website 1










Mission Statement
I am an archaeologist asking anthropological questions about the human past. I think archaeology is uniquely positioned at the intersection of science and humanities, and in some ways, enables us to unite the capabilities of both spheres of scientific inquiry. The process by which we collect and process data and thereby produce a narrative of the past parallels the way the past is revealed to us by the creators of the objects and their narratives. Thus, how we apply open science in today’s world not only has a direct bearing on data integrity and transparency, but also shapes the development of equitable narratives in science and society at large (where we combat rampant misinformation and confirmation biases). There is considerable distance between the way Open Science reforms are being expedited in the natural and social sciences today and how humanities are leveraging these practices to gain fresh perspectives that authentically showcase the human experience. I am interested in how we close that gap.

Mission Statement:

Mission Statement


I am a statistician and epidemiologist at the Bavarian Health and Food Safety Authority, Privatdozent (Adjunct Lecturer) at TU München, and Academic Editor for PLOS ONE.

I realized already at a very early stage of my career how scientific results can be affected by subjective / doubtful decisions made before, during or even after the data analysis process, such as lack of a clear pre-specified hypothesis, preliminary analysis during the time of data collection, data analysis without well-documented or even any program code, or p-hacking. I make my program codes publicly available, wherever possible, and in the role of a reviewer or editor, I always ask the authors of submitted papers to do likewise.

Mission Statement
I am a postdoctoral researcher in the Social Psychology group at LMU Munich. Reproducibility and transparency are of vital importance to me, both theoretically and practically. Theoretically, part of my research is dedicated to identifying and examining the factors influencing the replicability of social psychological research. Practically, in my own research, I am committed to maintaining a high level of transparency by openly sharing materials, research data, and published manuscripts whenever possible, through Open Access options or pre-prints. Additionally, I consider sample size planning and preregistration to be essential standards for replicable research, which I have consistently applied to my own work and advocated for as a reviewer for academic journals and in supervising student theses.

title: Wolfgang Strube
text:

Faculty of 



larissa.neumann@med.uni-muenchen.de



Website 1










Mission Statement
Mission Statement:

I am currently a research scholar at the UC San Diego Health Department of Biomedical Informatics, USA, and a research assistant at the Institute for Medical Information Processing, Biometry, and Epidemiology (IBE), LMU, Germany. I practice anesthesiology at the Medical Center of the University of Munich (LMU Klinikum), with additional experience in critical care. In December 2018, I joined the working group Anesthesia & Critical Care Informatics and Data Analysis Group (ACID).

My research interests are in perioperative medicine and developing predictive models for critically ill patients. In addition to exploring machine learning methods to personalize blood transfusion triggers, I am excited about being a team member of building an Observational Medical Outcomes Partnership (OMOP) Common Data Model (CDM) data warehouse to establish a cross-institutional distributed ledger.

In my current project, Reliable Response Data Discovery for COVID-19 Clinical Consults using Patient Observations, many health institutions answer COVID-19 questions by consulting, in a privacy-protecting manner, data from electronic health records. We share concept definitions, query codes, and results to allow reproducibility. 'Open Science' can be the key for impactful research.

Mission Statement
I am a postdoctoral researcher with the Social Psychology group at LMU Munich. My research focuses on trust in and within science. As my and others’ research in this area shows, the ideas of Open Science are important for (re)building trust in science – both the public’s trust in science as well as trust among researchers. I am committed to implementing openness and transparency in every step of my own research, I encourage it in my reviews, as well as in cooperation with colleagues and students, and I make it a topic while teaching the next generation of psychologists.

title: Heidi Seibold
text:
Trainer and Consultant
Faculty of NA



heidi@seibold.co



Website 1










Mission Statement


I am an advocate for open and reproducible research. I teach courses on good scientific practice and computational reproducibility and try to improve the way the research community operates.

title: Mario Gollwitzer
text:
Head of Department
Faculty of Psychology & Education



mario.gollwitzer@psy.lmu.de










Mission Statement


I am professor of Social Psychology at the Department of Psychology. The recent discussions about the replicability of psychological effects gave me some pause. I hope (and somehow believe) that "open science" has the potential to increase replicability rates and to raise the quality of psychological research. As member of the executive board of the German Psychological Society, I have contributed to the development and implementation of recommendations regarding data sharing in the scientific community. In my own lab, I encourage the use of open science practices and a full commitment to openness and transparency in our research projects.

title: Julian Unkel
text:
Department of Media and Communication
Faculty of 



julian.unkel@ifkw.lmu.de










Mission Statement
Mission Statement:

I am a postdoctoral researcher at the Department of Media and Communication. My field has been slowly but steadily adapting open science practices in the last few years. I try to promote open science by consequently following open science standards in my own research, by contributing to open-source research software development, and by integrating topics such as preregistration and reproducibility into my course syllabi. I am also part of an international multi-author team that suggests “An agenda for open science in Communication” in the Journal of Communication.

Mission Statement
Mission Statement: 

My research is at the intersection of psychology and data-driven sciences. For my own work, it is very important to me to be transparent and to share analysis code, materials, and data (while respecting data privacy issues) to make a sustainable contribution to research in my field. In my teaching, I try to infect students with my enthusiasm for Open Science and thus to sensitize young people for Open Science.

title: Sabine Hoffmann
text:
Head of statistical consulting laboratory StaBLab, Institute of Statistics
Faculty of Math, Informatics & Statistics



sabine.hoffmann@stat.uni-muenchen.de



Website 1










Mission Statement
I am head of the statistical consulting laboratory StaBLab.

As a trained statistician, psychologist and epidemiologist, I believe that multidisciplinary initiatives like the LMU Open Science Center are very important to promote open science practices. Moreover, we do not only need to promote transparency in research, but also to provide guidance on how to apply research methods in a way that will improve the replicability of research findings. In my teaching and in my research, I try to foster open science practices by providing guidance on pre-registration, adjustment for multiple testing and other ways to deal with analytical choices in the analysis of empirical data. In my consulting activities, I try to promote the use of suitable methods to model the complexities of research projects and to improve the communication of research findings. Overall, I think that it is more important than ever that we make research as transparent, credible and reliable as possible.

As a consultant, I try to propagate good statistical practice in the applied sciences. As an educator, I try to raise awareness and sensitivity for open science issues like p-hacking and reproducibility. In my own research, I try to adhere to open science principles whenever possible, e.g., by sharing code and data, and by making manuscripts open access.

I also encourage openness and transparency in all research projects conducted at the Institute of Finno-Ugric Studies.

Mission Statement:

Our goal is to improve patient outcomes after lung transplantation, predicting rejection of the donor organ by finding biomarkers or patterns in the clinical data. I would like to advocate for adopting open science practices in the field of clinical research, opening possibilites to „team science“ via data sharing while protecting sensitive patient data.

Mission Statement

I am postdoctoral researcher at the chair of Quantitative Methods of Social Research (Department of Sociology). Besides my interest in researching the causes and contextual factors of social inequality using also meta-analytical tools I do methodological research on detection methods of publication bias and the assessment of scientific integrity. I am convinced that norms of transparency, sharing data and analysis files as well as establishing good practices of replication, and further interventions of open science are important to advance the quality as well as increase the efficiency of science.

title: Alp Kaan Aksu
text:
BSc Student
Faculty of Psychology & Education



os@alpkaanaksu.com



Website 1










Mission Statement
I am currently studying psychology at the LMU and computer science at TUM. Even before I started studying psychology, I had a lot of questions related to good scientific practice, and few weeks into my first psychology semester at the LMU, I learned about the Open Science movement (thanks to the ReproducibiliTea Journal Club!). I think it is very valuable to learn more about Open Science, to talk about it with others, to come up with new questions and to try to find answers together. This is why I joined the ReproducibiliTea Journal Club. I am now part of the organisation team of this Journal Club as I think it is one of the best places to start raising awareness about Open Science and spreading good scientific practice among students, since mostly bachelor's and master's students attend our meetings. On a related note, I am also interested in science communication and how we can make scientific knowledge accesible to everyone.

Mission Statement

In my own research, I try my best to publish reproducible analysis code, make available or use open data, and convince my coauthors to publish preprints or select journals with sustainable open access policies. In the future, I hope to contribute to meta scientific research to increase the replicability of psychological science.

Mission Statement
Mission Statement: 

I am professor for Romance Linguistics.

Our data must be findable, accessible, interoperable and reusable. Reasonable rules for transparency and openness in research is to the benefit of the community of researchers and an obvious indicator of its vitality. Those who reject this social contract accept the disappearance of numerous, not least small, disciplines traditionally labelled with the (very German) name of 'Geisteswissenschaften'.

Looking back to 20 years of wet lab research I realized that I hardly ever designed an experiment properly. This is a common problem that will not be solved by top-down measures but by systematic education of new generations of scientists.

I believe that making science more transparent and open to the public is of paramount importance to maintain its credibility and increase its weight in public decision making. patrick.schenk@lmu.de

To me, “Open Science is just good science in a digital age,” as Heidi Seibold put it. I believe that statisticians, through their dual role– conducting own research and supporting researchers from other disciplines– are well-positioned to contribute meaningfully to Open Science. In teaching, collaborating with non-statisticians, and supporting colleagues, I aim to increase data and statistical literacy as well as promote good scientific practices. In my research, I strive to both implement Open Science practices myself and explore how problems, such as the reproducibility crisis, are connected to the foundations of statistics.

Scientific Coordinator of the OSC




  





  


  


  


  







Malika Ihle



Dr.


Open Science Center



Malika Ihle is the LMU Open Science Center Coordinator, supporting the scientific board in developing a comprehensive approach to open research that extends across all disciplines, using both bottom-up and top-down strategies. Her role is to provide peer-to-peer training and develop an open research curriculum, coordinate grassroots initiatives and organise various events such as seminars and conferences, support meta-research collaborations, liaise with local, national (e.g. the German Reproducibility Network (GRN)), and international stakeholders to inform the design of incentives and policies, and co-develop a strategic plan to make the LMU Open Science Center a sustainable entity.

title: LMU Open Science Summer School 2025
text:
Philologicum Library, Ludwigstraße 25, 80539 Munich 
          
        
        
    
    
        
            📅 Date & Time
            15 -19 September, 202514:00 - 17:00 CET
        
        
            🌐 Language
            English(German Q&A available)
        
        
            💻 Format
            Hybrid EventIn-person & Online
        
    
    
        Register
    




Overview
The LMU Open Science Center (OSC) is excited to announce the call for applications for its 5th hybrid summer school (OSSS25): deadline July 14!
This year’s iteration has two tracks to provide participants with two sets of skills. You are invited to apply for one or both tracks. For either track, you can choose to participate either online or in-person.
Track 1: Open Science knowledge and skills
In this track, early career researchers who are Open Science novices learn to make their research more transparent, reproducible and credible in the eyes of their peers, the public, and funding agencies. This track consists of public lectures accessible to anyone as well as hands-on practical workshops for selected applicants and extends from Monday 15.09.2025 9:00 to Friday 19.09.2025 14:30.
Participants of this track learn how to:

Specify research design and set up statistical plans in advance of collecting data to prevent biases in analyses, with the help of preregistration and data simulation.
Create computationally reproducible workflows to be more efficient and spot mistakes in data wrangling or analyses, through programming with version controlled scripts.
Prepare and share data and code in connection with manuscripts by applying the Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable principles, and using adequate repositories and licenses to accumulate credit and citations.

Track 2: Open Science instructor training
In this track, early career researchers or research support staff interested in becoming Open Science instructors develop essential pedagogical skills to promote Open Science through teaching - no prior experience in teaching required. This track extends from Friday 19.09.2025 14:30 to 17:30.
Participants of this track learn how to:

Design and deliver Open Science workshops, and apply basic didactic techniques to diverse audiences.
Apply activation methods in the classroom to foster motivation and attention.
Develop skills to advocate for Open Science, to lead research groups and discussions around Open Science, and to analyse the potential challenges and issues around the implementation of Open Science practices.

After joining this track, you will have the opportunity to put your new skills into practice and co-deliver a workshop at LMU to become a certified Open Science instructor.


Keynote presenters


Laura Meier
Maximilian Frank
Florian Kohrt




Questions?
We are looking forward to your participation! For any questions, please contact us at osc@lmu.de

title: Reproducible processes
text:
Introduction to R


Learn the basics of the R programming language















Introduction to Version Control within RStudio


Explore the git version control software and its integrations with the popular RStudio interactive development environment















Collaborative coding with GitHub and RStudio


After learning the basics of git, apply your skills in an interactive tutorial















Advanced git


Learn git features like branching and gitflow, and how to take advantage of issues, pull requests, and more on GitHub















Introduction to Quarto


Discover the basics of setting up computationally reproducible analyses, manuscripts, and presentations















Introduction to Zotero


Easily save your sources to the Zotero software, and learn how to insert these citations into your documents















Introduction to {renv}


Make your projects reproducible by learning how to (easily) manage your R packages

Scientific Coordinator of the OSC




  





  


  


  


  







Malika Ihle



Dr.


Open Science Center



Malika Ihle is the LMU Open Science Center Coordinator, supporting the scientific board in developing a comprehensive approach to open research that extends across all disciplines, using both bottom-up and top-down strategies. Her role is to provide peer-to-peer training and develop an open research curriculum, coordinate grassroots initiatives and organise various events such as seminars and conferences, support meta-research collaborations, liaise with local, national (e.g. the German Reproducibility Network (GRN)), and international stakeholders to inform the design of incentives and policies, and co-develop a strategic plan to make the LMU Open Science Center a sustainable entity.

Read More!

title: Giovanni Picogna
text:
Researcher
Faculty of Physics



picogna@usm.lmu.de



Website 1










Mission Statement


I am a postdoctoral researcher at the Observatory of the LMU, working on planet formation. During my career I have come to understand how essential is openness into the scientific process, and how much it can help it to spur. I work with numerical simulations to recreate observations, in order to understand the physical processes at the base of planet formation. Many details can be hidden under the carpet, both from the observational and numerical side. In my work I am trying to explain all the assumptions made during my work, and I am planning to render more public all the codes and data used during the simulations and in the post-processing phase.

title: Daniel Keeser
text:

daniel.keeser@med.uni-muenchen.de

Mission Statement

title: Anna Sophie Kümpel
text:
Chair
Faculty of Social Sciences



Thomas.Kuhr@lmu.de



Website 1










Mission Statement
I am leading the Experimental Flavor Physics Group that is studying the fundamental laws of physics with data from the Belle II experiment in Japan.As the effort of collecting large amounts of particle collision data is very high, it is important to optimally exploit the recorded data. I am convinced that this is best achieved by Open Science. This requires that the FAIR principles are not only applied to data, but also the to the whole infrastructure required for the analysis of the data, including in particular the software. I have led a task force to established an Open Source Software Policy at the international Belle II collaboration and taken care of the publication of its main software. I am also working on technologies that facilitate the reuse and reinterpretation of data.

title: Maximilian Frank
text:
PhD Candidate
Faculty of Psychology & Education



maximilian.frank@psy.lmu.de



Website 1










Mission Statement
My name is Maximilian Frank and I am a doctoral candidate at the Ludwig-Maximilians-University of Munich in the DFG priority program "META-REP" and conduct research on heterogeneity estimations in meta-analyses. Back the time of my psychology studies, I was lucky to be assigned to emprical course (EmPra) in which we conducted a replication of an existing study. This was my first point of contact with the topic replication crisis and the many proposals for reforming science that can be summarized under the term "Open Science". Since then, the topic has stuck with me and I have consequently become involved in several Open Science initiatives. Personally, in addition to a transparent and reproducible work process in my own research, I am engaged in teaching Open Science practices to students and early career researchers. They are the scientists of the future, which is why we owe them a state-of-the-art education which covers these important topics to benefit science as a whole.

title: Ulrich Mansmann
text:
Director of Institute
Faculty of Medicine



Markus.Maier@psy.lmu.de



Website 1










Mission Statement
I am professor for General Psychology (Emotion and Motivation) at the Department of Psychology.

Good scientific research practices require large sample studies as well as confirmatory studies. As such, the chair of General Psychology II established a lab that aims to help researchers to effectively and quickly run their studies under controlled conditions.

B.Osimani@lmu.de

I am an assistant professor at the Munich Center for Mathematical Philosophy.

title: Sara Lil Middleton
text:
Research Support
Faculty of NA



anton.marx@psy.lmu.de



Website 1










Mission Statement
I am a psychologist and licensed psychotherapist (CBT) for children and adolescents at the department of psychology at the University of Munich (LMU). In my research as well as my teaching activities, I embrace the values of openness and transparency in science. That is why I signed the „Commitment to Research Transparency and Open Science“ and strive to conduct open, transparent, reproducible, and credible research.

title: Christian L. Müller
text:
Chair
Faculty of Math, Informatics & Stats



christian.mueller@stat.uni-muenchen.de










Mission Statement
I'm a group leader at the Institute of Computational Biology at the Helmholtz Zentrum München and a Professor for Biomedical Statistics and Data Science at the Department of Statistics.

I deeply care about open source software development in statistics and optimization and encourage students and collaborators to use public code repositories, open preprint servers, and permanent object identifiers for data sets for any of our research projects. In addition, I support fully reproducible open access analysis workflows accompanying any of our statistical or computational scientific articles.

title: Katrin Auspurg
text:
Chair
Faculty of Social Sciences



matthias@stat.uni-muenchen.de



Website 1










Mission Statement
I am a postdoctoral researcher at the Chair of Statistical Learning and Data Science (Dept. of Statistics, LMU) and the NFDI Consortium for Business, Economic and Related Data (BERD@NFDI).

In my role as a lecturer, I try to convey the principles and values of open science and open data to the students. As a researcher in Machine Learning and Natural Language Processing, I stick to the open science principles by publishing data and code as well as by making my research papers open access. Being part of BERD@NFDI also means fostering open science culture, with a special focus on enabling other researchers to share their data and algorithms more easily.

title: Laura Goetz
text:
MSc Student
Faculty of Medicine, Psychology & Education



laura.goetz@campus.lmu.de










Mission Statement
I’m currently studying Medicine and Psychology. During my Psychology studies back in 2018, I first heard about Open Science. Since then, I’ve tried to conduct Open Science methods in my work (especially preregistration, open data and materials) and encourage my fellow students to engage with Open Science. That’s why two of my colleagues and I founded a journal club back in 2019, in which we discuss papers and topics around Open Science. I am convinced that the Open Science movement will be most successful if we talk about it, discuss it, inform about it and support local initiatives.

Mission Statement:

We get to see what we should keep and what we should change from the old science way. For what I have seen, the change is difficult but the tools are there. title: Justin Sulik
text:
Researcher
Faculty of Philosophy



justin.sulik@lmu.de



Website 1










Mission Statement
I study the psychology of science. This includes investigating the cognitive traits and social contexts of scientists as they collaborate to solve complex problems. I also explore the traits and contexts of laypeople as they try to understand our modern world, especially cases where people distrust science or reject scientific consensus on topics such as climate change or vaccine safety. My main engagement with Open Science is in the sharing and development of best practice for assessing and improving data quality in online questionnaires and experiments. In order to make transparent decisions about how (or whether) to filter poor-quality responses, and to evaluate how these decisions might impact conclusions, we need open survey materials, transparent reporting of data-quality indexes, reproducible data-processing scripts and detailed quality-assessment scripts.

Since then, I have been involved in a number of local and nationwide projects to promote OS. For example, I co-authored a paper on QRPs among students, contributed to two position papers on implementing Open Science in teaching and I am still organising the journal club "ReproducibiliTea" at LMU Munich. Personally, I am convinced that the OS movement will be most successful if it allows critical voices, maintains dialogue with dissenters and works towards strengthening local OS-communities.

I am a MSc student in Epidemiology at the Institute for Medical Information Processing, Biometry, and Epidemiology (IBE). My interests lie particularly in improving scientific reproducibility by teaching software development practices, and in creating data analysis tools which can be used to assess replicability of research findings. I believe treating scientific analyses as if they were software development projects helps facilitate standard, understandable frameworks which can play a large role in addressing issues of reproducibility and replicability of research findings.

Mission Statement
Mission Statement:

My research aims at clarifying how key aspects of social behaviours in animals, such as their genetic architecture and phenotypic plasticity, alter the potential for sociality to evolve. I am working towards using Open Science practices more systematically in my own research, e.g. providing pre-registered reports, usable datasets and analysis code. I am also interested in communicating about Open Science ideas and improving research practices in my field.

Mission Statement
I am a postdoc in the Social Psychology unit at LMU. My research focus is judgement and decision making in social contexts. I am part of the DFG-funded consortium "META-REP" on determinants of replicability. I am convinced that open science routines can and should be an integral component of robust, genuine, and reliable research.

title: Gitta Kutyniok
text:
Chair
Faculty of Math, Informatics & Stats



kutyniok@math.lmu.de



Website 1










Mission Statement
I am head of the Bavarian AI Chair for Mathematical Foundations of Artificial Intelligence. In our research we aim for ensuring reliability of AI-based methods through a profound mathematical understanding and providing possibilites to explain the results. Recently, we detected theoretically that digital hardware causes serious limitations for AI, leading to research in the direction of software-solutions for analog hardware such as neuromorphic computing and quantum computing. Finally, we apply artificial intelligence in a trustworthy manner to problems from medical imaging, robotics, and telecommunication.

Research in the area of artificial Intelligence requires extensive amounts of data. From my viewpoint, reproducibility of experiments is not sufficiently considered at present. Hence I am a strong supporter of incorporating more open science practices into AI research.

Mission Statement
Mission Statement:

I am a Principle Investigator at the Department of Neurology in Klinikum Großhadern. My primary research interest is in how pain is processed in the human brain.

I have observed that not all study participants exhibited the effects that are reported in group statistics, indicating that results reported in publications are highly dependent on the study sample. In my experience results have been withheld because they were not in line with previously published findings.Therefore I am planning to make my data and my code publicly available.

Faculty of Psychology & Education



v.wiegelmann@campus.lmu.de










Mission Statement
I’m currently studying Psychology at the LMU. I first heard about the Open Science movement in my Statistics Course during my first semester and was excited to be already able to implement some of the ideas during my first Research Practical (e.g. preregistration, open data). Ever since I am interested in what it means to conduct good (psychological) scientific research. This is also why I joined the organisation team of the Open Science Journal Club this semester, which I find a great way to broaden my horizon in the world of Open Science. I believe that in order to make a difference it is necessary to start by informing and educating as many people as possible about Open Science, but also keep discussing the challenges and limitations it may face.

Mission Statement:

title: Felix Schönbrodt
text:
Managing Director of the OSC
Faculty of Psychology & Education



Felix.Schoenbrodt@psy.lmu.de










Mission Statement
Mission Statement: 

I am principal investigator for Psychological Methods and Assessment at the Department of Psycholgoy.

The reproducibility of research findings is a core criterion of science, which however, has been challenged by the failure of recent large-scale replication projects. To foster open science practices, I teamed up with colleagues and established our department's "Open Science Committee" in 2015. The outcomes of this committee include an open science paragraph which we included in all recent professorship job descriptions, adding transparency criteria to the department's performance-based funding system, or introducing modules on preregistrations, open data, and reproducible scripts as mandatory components in undergraduate courses.

Together with the board of the German Psychological Society (DGPs) I developed the society's recommendations for data sharing in psychology [English version]. In 2016, I received the Leamer-Rosenthal-Prize for Open Social Science from the Berkeley Initiative for Transparency in the Social Sciences (BITSS).
